Dear Cathey Prudhomme:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on February 25, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (a) The date the information was
received.
One of three special investigations did not have a written report completed within
15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation as required.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as
applicable; the department; and the foster
child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:

• (iv) Any medical and mental illness
or condition that results in
treatment at a hospital emergency
room or inpatient hospitalization of
a foster child.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an incident
report was completed when a foster youth received treatment at a hospital
emergency room.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
One of three independent living files reviewed had a Updated Service Plan
submitted outside of the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/7/2024 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/8/2024

• There was no technical assistance requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 1 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2024SEC0001791 was initiated on 7/2/2024 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline.

The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. A CAP was recommended and is still in place.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency interim inspection was completed on 3/7/24 and the CAP was approved on
4/8/24. The agency was cited for 5 violations, 1 of which was repeated this year.
There was improvement in individual incidents of non-compliance for the repeat
violation. In 2023, 3 violations were established, 1 of which was repeated this
year. There was improvement in individual incidents of non-compliance. The
agency will need to establish additional corrective planning for the repeated
violation to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency continues to meet or close to meeting the required
performance standards for the 10 key performance indicators. The agency meets
regularly to review data and troubleshoot if something is missed to determine the
reason and methods to prevent. The chief administrator indicated the previous
year CAP had a positive impact. There will be additional adjustments to address
any repeat violations.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the agency's
financial audit.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisor and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff reported the agency is consistent in providing and reviewing
information during team meetings. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: The licensed foster home was found to lack smoke detectors
between the bedrooms and the rest of the home and also in the basement.
Resolution: A special evaluation was initiated as a result of the non-compliance. A
smoke alarm was installed between the bedrooms and also in the basement. The
agency provided pictures as verification.

Safety Alert #2: The unlicensed relative home had cleaning supplies that were
accessible to young children in the home.
Resolution: The cleaning supplies were moved from under the kitchen sink to the
cabinets above the washer and dryer. The agency provided pictures as verification.
Safety Alert #3: The unlicensed relative home was found to lack a smoke detector
between the caregiver's bedroom and the rest of the home. In addition, the home
had weapons that were not stored securely.
Resolution: A smoke alarm was installed between the caregiver's bedroom and the
rest of the home. The agency provided pictures as verification. The unlicensed
caregiver purchased a gun safe, and all of the weapons are secured in the safe.
The agency provided pictures as verification.
Safety Alert #4: The unlicensed relative home was found to lack a smoke detector
between the sleeping area and the rest of the home.
Resolution: A smoke alarm was installed between the sleeping area and the rest of
the home. The agency provided a picture as verification.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
